Stonehenge mystery deepens: Scientists say the altar stone did NOT come from Orkney as previously claimed in bombshell study - as the hunt for its origin continues

The origin of Stonehenge's iconic standing stones has baffled archaeologists for hundreds of years. Last month, the plot thickened as scientists made a bombshell discovery that the stone circle's altar stone (pictured left) could be traced back to Scotland, rather than Wales. Now, the mystery has deepened once again as a new study finds that this bluestone slab did not originate from Orkney (illustrated right) as most experts had assumed. 'The mystery of where the stone came from is becoming clearer and clearer as we begin to rule out specific areas in north-east Scotland,' said Professor Richard Bevins from Aberystwyth University, the lead author of the new study. 'This research is radically changing our thinking about the origins of the Altar Stone. It's thrilling to know that our chemical analysis and dating work is slowly unlocking this great mystery.'

Derelict warehouse transformed into £750,000 luxury home goes on the market just 10 years after it was snapped up for £72,000

A derelict warehouse surrounded by factories is on the market for £795,000 after it was converted into a luxury home. The 100-year-old building, was bought for £72,000 in 2016, and stands in the centre of the industrial heartlands of North Shields near Newcastle. Despite its unassuming appearance, inside is an impressive three-storey modern home boasting a huge open-plan kitchen and dining area. The offices on the top floor have been converted into a smart terrace boasting views across the River Tyne.
